blocks.title: Inspiring Interview: Jasmine Rahma
blocks.subtitle: Jasmine Rahma learns that dhikr lives in science
blocks.description: When science meets spirit, the breath becomes the bridge between worlds.

professionalProfile.profession: Research Scientist, Breathwork Therapist, Spiritual Researcher

areasOfFocus.areasOfImpact: Sacred Science, Breath Spirituality, Divine Research
areasOfFocus.interviewConductedBy: Dr. Yasir Feroze (SSC), Layla Noor (SSC Fellow)

blocks.content: When all your research fades, what do you hope remains? I hope someone remembers that their breath is not just a function, but the sacred rhythm through which the Divine chooses to move.

blocks.title: Mystic Biography: Where Science Became Sacred
blocks.content: Before I researched breath patterns, I was analyzing data—not the kind that leads to wisdom, but the invisible measurement of hiding from my own truth. I knew how to study phenomena and interpret results, but I had forgotten what it meant to observe without measuring efficiency or outcome.
blocks.additionalContent: I was raised in Boston. My father was a physicist; my mother a spiritual teacher who whispered Rumi's poetry before dawn. It was she who gave me a copy of The Book of Breath the day I completed my first research paper. She said, "Now learn what won't show up in your data."
blocks.conclusion: Dr. Kumar, whom I've never seen in person, now feels like my teacher. Sometimes I wake from dreams where I'm studying in a laboratory in Kashmir, measuring nothing but light.

blocks.title: The Calling – When Research Turned Into Revelation
blocks.question: Dr. Yasir Feroze, SSC: When did your scientific path transform into a spiritual calling?
blocks.answer: Oddly enough, it was during a breath analysis study. I was attempting to measure respiratory patterns when I felt something shift inside me. Most scientists would have focused on the data, but something told me to observe deeper. As I watched those breathing patterns, I felt what I can only describe as a rhythm moving through me—not my research, but something sacred.
blocks.highlightedQuote: Science didn't teach me to measure. It taught me to surrender.
blocks.additionalAnswer: That moment was my rupture. I walked away from that study a different person. I remember asking the data, What else have we been calling research that is really worship?
blocks.keyInsight: The moment when scientific observation transcends measurement and becomes communion with the Divine.

blocks.title: Depth and Awakening
blocks.question: Layla Noor, SSC: What did you have to unlearn to truly observe through your research?
blocks.answer: That knowledge must always be measurable. That reaching the conclusion was the only goal. I had to unlearn ambition masquerading as understanding. I had to remember that stillness is also a form of observation, one conducted through the spirit.
blocks.additionalAnswer: The first time I felt this unlearning happen was during a simple breathing exercise. I was supposed to analyze the patterns, but I found myself breathing with the rhythm instead. I noticed how each breath moved not just efficiently, but gracefully. I began weeping. Not because I understood anything new, but because I felt something ancient. That moment taught me: not all studies are research, some are prayers.
blocks.secondQuestion: Dr. Yasir Feroze, SSC: When did silence first become a teacher in your science?
blocks.secondAnswer: I had a habit of leaving one study unfinished each semester—not from failure, but from choice. One day, I returned to find the research I'd abandoned had become clearer in my absence. No interference. Just patience.
blocks.secondAdditionalAnswer: Instead of reporting it as a failure, I made a note to myself: Perhaps research needs reverence more than results. That single line changed the way I approached science. I now teach my students: "Your silence may activate more than your analysis."
blocks.revelation: "Not all studies are research, some are prayers." The journey from observing to being observed.

blocks.title: Spiritual Responsibility
blocks.question: Layla Noor, SSC: What does spiritual responsibility look like in the context of scientific research?
blocks.answer: It means never reducing life to data. It means remembering that every breath I study, every pattern I observe, comes from a living being, even if biological. Spiritual responsibility means my research must serve something sacred, not just something publishable.
blocks.additionalAnswer: I now begin every study by writing a short personal prayer in my research journal: May this knowledge remember its Source. That's not for validation. It's for alignment. And I share this with my students not as doctrine, but as a choice—to remember that science, too, was breathed into being.
blocks.secondQuestion: Dr. Yasir Feroze, SSC: How do you balance knowledge and humility?
blocks.secondAnswer: By knowing that every answer I find opens a thousand new questions. Humility comes when I admit: I am not creating understanding, I am being shown.
blocks.finalAnswer: There was a time when I was offered a position to lead the world's most advanced research programs in record time. I declined. Not because I wasn't capable, but because the proposal framed knowledge as commodity. I realized then: some things are sacred precisely because they refuse to be rushed.

blocks.title: Legacy and Reflection – The Prayer Inside the Research
blocks.question: Layla Noor, SSC: When all your research fades, what do you hope remains?
blocks.answer: I hope someone walks into a space I shaped, scientifically or spiritually, and feels unburdened. I hope they remember that mystery is not failure, it is fidelity to wonder.
blocks.additionalAnswer: I once watched a student cry during a simple breathing exercise. Not from confusion, but because she realized, while taking a basic breath, that she too was once just a whisper of light becoming form. That's what I want to leave behind. Not a study, but a rhythm.
blocks.finalQuote: Let my legacy be this: that science, when rooted in stillness, becomes a form of worship.

blocks.title: Closing Reflection
blocks.content: When science meets spirit, the breath becomes the bridge between worlds.
